clinical_note: Richard Green is a 13-year-old boy with a history notable for intermittent episodes of confusion, lethargy, and rapid breathing, often occurring during intercurrent illnesses. Parents describe several events over the past two years in which he developed sudden unresponsiveness with generalized shaking and postictal somnolence, without clear provoking factors. These events have raised concern for recurrent seizures, and he is currently under neurological evaluation. Between episodes, he returns to his baseline and is attending school with age-appropriate academic performance. Laboratory studies obtained during acute events have repeatedly shown abnormalities in blood acid–base balance, with elevated acid levels requiring intravenous fluids and close monitoring, raising suspicion for an underlying metabolic vulnerability contributing to his decompensations and seizure tendency. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that resolved in adolescence, and a paternal grandfather with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. There is no known history of similar metabolic crises or unexplained early deaths in the family.

Ruth Rivera is a 9‑year‑old girl with a longstanding history of congenital anomalies and developmental concerns. Since infancy, she has been followed for a structural heart defect characterized by an abnormal connection between the upper heart chambers, with intermittent exertional fatigue but no reported cyanotic episodes. Early feeding was complicated by difficulty swallowing solid foods, later attributed to a congenital narrowing at the junction of the throat and esophagus, requiring careful dietary modification. Developmentally, she has moderate intellectual impairment, with delayed language acquisition and ongoing need for support in academic and adaptive skills; she attends a specialized education program and requires assistance with daily living tasks. Physical examination has consistently noted a pattern of congenital body differences, including subtle facial asymmetry and disproportion of body segments suggestive of an underlying syndromic diagnosis. A prior gene panel performed on 2025‑09‑30 was reported as negative, without identification of a causative variant. No significant family history of similar congenital anomalies or developmental difficulties has been documented.

William Clark is a 9-year-old boy with a history notable for congenital craniofacial and ear anomalies identified in early infancy. He was born with marked asymmetry of the external ears, including malformation of the pinnae and abnormal positioning, accompanied by a high anterior hairline and subtle facial disproportion suggestive of an underlying craniofacial patterning defect. Neuroimaging in infancy demonstrated incomplete development of the cerebral hemispheres consistent with a form of brain malformation involving the forebrain, and he has shown persistent global developmental delay with slow acquisition of motor and language milestones. Ongoing concerns include short stature and poor overall growth velocity relative to age peers, raising suspicion for an underlying syndromic etiology affecting growth and development. Physical examination has repeatedly documented dysmorphic facial features with a constellation suggestive of a recognizable genetic syndrome involving multiple systems. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-08, which was reported as negative, and he is now referred for further comprehensive genomic assessment to better define the diagnosis and guide management.

Sandra Baker is an 8-year-old girl with a history notable for early-life neuromuscular difficulties, including generalized hypotonia and delayed attainment of gross motor milestones. Caregivers describe persistent “floppiness” in infancy, with ongoing challenges in maintaining posture and endurance during physical activities. Clinical concerns include intermittent episodes of fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance, raising suspicion for an underlying metabolic disturbance affecting energy utilization. Growth has been appropriate, but parents report occasional poor stamina during common childhood illnesses. Neurologic examination has previously documented low muscle tone with preserved strength, and no clear evidence of progressive weakness or regression. There is a reported family history of neuromuscular symptoms in a maternal uncle, who required physical therapy for low muscle tone in childhood, though he now functions independently. In addition, a paternal grandfather has type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease, and a maternal grandmother has osteoporosis, without known neurologic involvement. No prior genetic testing has been documented, and the family is seeking further evaluation to clarify the etiology of Sandra’s neuromuscular and suspected metabolic issues.

Karen Ramirez is a 13-year-old girl with a history notable for intermittent episodes concerning for seizure activity, described as brief periods of unresponsiveness with generalized stiffening and occasional rhythmic jerking, followed by post-event fatigue and confusion. Events reportedly began in mid-childhood and occur without clear triggers, including at rest and during routine activities. There is no history of head trauma or CNS infection. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal laboratory findings on prior metabolic screening, with repeatedly elevated serum markers suggesting an underlying biochemical disturbance, though a specific diagnosis has not yet been established. Parents report occasional headaches and mild dizziness around the time of these episodes but deny prolonged vomiting, failure to thrive, or regression of skills. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset seizures now well controlled on medication, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. No known consanguinity is reported. Karen is currently attending school with age-appropriate academic performance between events.

Timothy Young is a 15-year-old male seen for ongoing neurological and metabolic concerns. Since early childhood, he has experienced progressive difficulty with coordination, characterized by an unsteady, wide-based gait and clumsiness with fine motor tasks such as handwriting and buttoning clothes. Teachers have reported that he frequently drops objects and has trouble participating in sports due to poor balance. Parents also describe intermittent tremulousness when reaching for items and a tendency to veer to one side when walking quickly. Metabolic history is notable for long-standing intolerance to dairy products, with abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools occurring within hours of milk or ice cream ingestion; symptoms improve with lactose-restricted diet and use of lactase supplements. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with “balance problems” beginning in mid-adulthood, requiring use of a cane, and a younger sister with similar, though milder, dairy-related gastrointestinal symptoms. No known consanguinity is reported. Timothy is otherwise in good health and takes no regular medications.

Barbara White is an 11-year-old girl with a longstanding history of significant intellectual impairment, functioning in the severe range and requiring assistance with most activities of daily living. Developmental delays were evident from early childhood, with late attainment of motor milestones and minimal progression in academic skills. Clinical concerns include multiple congenital anomalies and a pattern of craniofacial differences consistent with an underlying syndromic diagnosis; exam has previously noted abnormal skull and facial configuration with asymmetry and disproportion, along with other subtle dysmorphic features. Since infancy, she has also been followed for congenital esophageal abnormalities, including a segment of narrowing and structural irregularity contributing to feeding difficulties and intermittent dysphagia. Growth has been variably affected over time, with attention to nutritional status due to her swallowing issues. A prior gene panel performed on 2025-07-30 was reported as negative, without identification of a pathogenic variant explaining her presentation. She continues to require multidisciplinary care for cognitive, behavioral, and medical support, and further genetic evaluation is being pursued.

Steven Rivera is a 10-year-old boy (born 2015-12-30) referred for ongoing neurological and metabolic concerns. Since early childhood, his history has been notable for intermittent elevations in laboratory markers suggestive of an underlying biochemical imbalance, with fluctuating abnormal serum values on routine testing that have not yet been fully explained. Parents describe episodes of decreased energy, poor tolerance of minor illnesses, and occasional irritability and tremulousness, particularly when he has not eaten for several hours. Neonatal history is notable for transient abnormalities in muscle tone, with periods of generalized stiffness alternating with reduced tone, which gradually improved but have left mild residual clumsiness and fatigability. Developmental milestones were ultimately achieved within broad normal limits, though he continues to struggle with endurance during physical activities compared with peers. There is a family history of a paternal uncle with “muscle problems” and difficulty maintaining energy during exertion, as well as a maternal cousin with unexplained abnormal liver function tests in adolescence. No known consanguinity is reported.

Betty Garcia is a 13-year-old girl with a history notable for significant global developmental delay and moderate to severe intellectual disability, with limited academic progress and ongoing need for special education services. Since early childhood, she has demonstrated multiple congenital anomalies, including a structural cardiac malformation involving the right ventricular outflow tract with associated valvular obstruction, for which she has been followed by pediatric cardiology. Ophthalmologic history includes a congenitally displaced eye with abnormal globe position and restricted extraocular movements, contributing to impaired depth perception. Renal history is notable for a cystic kidney disease characterized by multiple bilateral cysts and progressive enlargement on serial imaging, with nephrology monitoring renal function. Dysmorphic features have been described, including a characteristic facial appearance with midface involvement and disproportionate growth, raising concern for an underlying syndromic overgrowth or malformation disorder. Chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-02-08 was reported as negative, without pathogenic copy number variants, and no prior molecular diagnosis has been established to date.

Joshua Scott is a 10-year-old boy with a history notable for significant global developmental delay and severe intellectual impairment, with limited expressive language and need for assistance in most activities of daily living. Since early childhood, caregivers have observed abnormal craniofacial development, including a long, narrow face with midface hypoplasia and a high-arched palate, along with a slender build and joint laxity suggestive of an underlying syndromic process. Ocular findings have included progressive outward deviation of one eye with intermittent visual misalignment, for which he is followed by ophthalmology. Ear anomalies are also present, with low-set, abnormally shaped external ears and a history of recurrent otitis media and suspected conductive hearing loss, currently under evaluation by ENT. Multiple minor congenital anomalies have been documented without involvement of major internal organs to date. Prior genetic evaluation with a targeted gene panel on 2025-11-28 was reportedly negative, without identification of a causative variant, and further comprehensive genomic testing is now being considered to clarify the etiology and guide management.

Jessica Harris is a 3-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent seizures beginning in early childhood, described as generalized convulsive episodes with loss of consciousness and postictal confusion. Events have occurred without clear provocation and have required emergency evaluation on several occasions. She is currently treated with antiseizure medication, with partial reduction in frequency but persistent breakthrough episodes. Development has been reported as otherwise appropriate for age. Clinical concerns also include a suspected inborn error of metabolism affecting aromatic amino acid handling, with prior episodes of irritability and decreased feeding during intercurrent illness, and biochemical studies suggesting an abnormality in tyrosine metabolism; confirmatory enzymatic and molecular workup is pending. There is a positive family history of seizure disorder in a maternal uncle, who developed epilepsy in adolescence and remains on long-term antiepileptic therapy. No known consanguinity is reported. Parents seek further clarification of the underlying etiology and guidance regarding prognosis and recurrence risk.

George Hill is a 17-year-old male with a history notable for intellectual disability in the moderate range, with persistent academic difficulties and need for support in activities of daily living. Since early childhood, caregivers have described delayed language acquisition and limited problem‑solving skills, though social engagement has generally been appropriate. Physical examination has consistently shown a pattern of distinctive craniofacial features suggestive of an underlying syndromic diagnosis, including subtle facial disproportion and minor skeletal anomalies. Clinical concerns also include a congenital cardiac defect involving the atrial septum, followed over time by cardiology, and the presence of multiple renal cysts detected on imaging, with ongoing nephrology surveillance but preserved kidney function to date. There is no known consanguinity or similarly affected relatives reported. Prior genetic evaluation included a single‑gene test performed on 2025-11-16, which was negative and did not establish a molecular diagnosis. Given the combination of congenital heart disease, cystic kidney changes, dysmorphic features, and moderate intellectual disability, a broader genomic study is being pursued to clarify the underlying etiology and guide management.

Michael Wilson is a 11-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent, unexplained seizure episodes beginning in early childhood, described as brief generalized convulsions with postictal confusion and no clear provoking factors. Clinical concerns also include long-standing gastrointestinal discomfort and dietary intolerance characterized by abdominal bloating, cramping, and loose stools occurring within hours of consuming dairy products, leading the family to largely restrict lactose-containing foods. Parents report occasional headaches and fatigue following these episodes but no clear developmental regression. Neurologic evaluation to date has not identified a structural brain lesion, and seizures have been variably responsive to standard antiseizure medication. There is no history of significant perinatal complications. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset seizures that remitted in adolescence, and a paternal grandmother with chronic “milk intolerance” requiring dairy avoidance. No known consanguinity is reported. Michael lives with his parents and attends school with generally appropriate academic performance, though he has missed several days this year due to seizure events and gastrointestinal symptoms.

Betty Scott is a 6-year-old girl with a history notable for global developmental delay, with persistent concerns about slow acquisition of motor and language milestones. Growth has been borderline with ongoing worries about overall physical development. Since early infancy, caregivers have noted abnormal head shape and asymmetry, and examination has consistently shown craniofacial disproportion with mild facial dysmorphism, including atypical cranial contour and subtly unbalanced facial features. Cardiac evaluation in early childhood identified a congenital malformation involving the outflow region of the right ventricle, for which she is followed by pediatric cardiology; no interventions have yet been documented in the record provided. Clinical concerns also include features suggestive of a broader congenital malformation syndrome, with a pattern of anomalies involving the craniofacial region and heart in the setting of developmental delay. There is no reported family history of similar developmental, structural, or syndromic findings. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-12-15, which was reported as negative, and further etiologic clarification is being sought.

Donna Miller is a 12-year-old girl with a history notable for complex congenital and developmental concerns. Since infancy, she has been followed for a structural cardiac malformation involving the pulmonary valve, associated with intermittent exertional fatigue and prior episodes of poor weight gain. Early feeding was complicated by a congenital esophageal abnormality with recurrent dysphagia and choking episodes, requiring modified diet and close gastrointestinal follow-up. Developmentally, she demonstrates severe intellectual impairment with limited expressive language, requiring full assistance for activities of daily living and attending a specialized education program. Physical examination over time has documented a pattern of multiple congenital anomalies with characteristic craniofacial features and disproportionate growth, raising concern for an underlying syndromic etiology. Dysmorphic features have been stable but distinctive enough to prompt referral for further genetic evaluation. Prior genetic testing with chromosomal microarray on 2025-06-27 was reported as negative, without identification of a pathogenic copy number change. She is now referred for additional genomic investigation to clarify an underlying diagnosis and guide ongoing management and family counseling.

Donna Williams is a 5-year-old girl with a history notable for global developmental delay, with persistent lag across motor and language milestones despite early intervention services. Parents report that she walked later than expected and continues to have clumsiness and difficulty with fine motor tasks. Growth has been monitored due to concerns about overall developmental progress, though no regression has been described. Since infancy, she has had distinctive craniofacial features, including a broad forehead and other subtle facial differences prompting concern for an underlying syndromic diagnosis. Ear anomalies, including malposition and abnormal shape, were noted on early examinations. Orthopedic evaluation identified congenital foot deformities consistent with abnormal positioning of the feet, and she has required bracing and physical therapy for gait abnormalities. No similar problems are reported in close relatives, and there is no known consanguinity. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-08, which was negative, and she is now referred for further genomic assessment to clarify an underlying genetic etiology and guide management.

Paul Moore is a 11-year-old boy with a history notable for global developmental delay in the moderate range, with significant impact on academic skills and adaptive functioning. Since early childhood, he has required special education support and continues to struggle with expressive language and problem-solving, though social engagement is generally appropriate. Birth and early growth were complicated by multiple congenital anomalies, including bilateral foot deformities consistent with clubfoot requiring early orthopaedic intervention, and structural abnormalities of the kidneys with evidence of cystic changes on prior imaging and ongoing nephrology follow-up. Clinical examination has repeatedly described a pattern of distinctive facial features and body proportions suggestive of an underlying congenital malformation syndrome, along with mild skeletal anomalies. There is no known family history of similar developmental or congenital problems. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-06-19, which was reported as negative, and no molecular diagnosis has yet been established. Further comprehensive genomic testing is being pursued to clarify the etiology of his constellation of congenital, renal, and neurodevelopmental findings.

Sarah Martinez is a 3-year-old girl with a history notable for congenital cranial abnormalities and global developmental concerns. Since infancy, her head shape has appeared asymmetric with persistent plagiocephaly and abnormal cranial contour, raising concern for an underlying structural brain malformation. Early neuroimaging reportedly demonstrated incomplete formation of the cerebral hemispheres consistent with a severe cortical developmental anomaly. Developmentally, she has demonstrated significant delays in both motor and language domains; parents describe limited expressive vocabulary, poor attention to tasks, and difficulty following age-appropriate commands, with ongoing concerns for impaired cognitive processing and learning. Exam has been notable for dysmorphic features, including abnormal craniofacial proportions and features suggestive of an underlying syndromic etiology. Clinical concerns include a possible connective tissue or skeletal dysplasia syndrome given her overall gestalt and growth pattern. There is no known family history of similar neurologic or craniofacial anomalies. Prior genetic testing included a single-gene analysis performed on 2025-11-30, which was negative, and further comprehensive genomic evaluation is being pursued.

Laura Jackson is a 9-year-old girl with a history notable for significant global developmental delay and severe intellectual impairment, with limited expressive language and need for assistance in most activities of daily living. Since early childhood, she has been followed for multiple congenital anomalies, including a complex congenital cardiac malformation involving the pulmonary valve and right ventricular outflow tract, for which she underwent early surgical repair and continues on cardiology surveillance. Renal evaluation has shown structural abnormalities of the collecting system consistent with a cystic dysplastic process, and she is monitored for blood pressure and renal function. Dysmorphic features have been described on prior examinations, including a characteristic facial gestalt and mild skeletal disproportion, raising concern for an underlying syndromic etiology. There is no documented family history of similar neurodevelopmental or structural anomalies. Prior genetic evaluation included a single-gene test performed on 2025-07-24, which was reported as negative, and no unifying molecular diagnosis has yet been established. Further comprehensive genetic testing is being pursued to clarify the underlying cause and guide management and counseling.

Steven Torres is a 14-year-old male with a history notable for moderate intellectual disability, with global developmental delays recognized in early childhood and persistent need for support in academic and adaptive functioning. Since infancy, he has had feeding difficulties attributed to a congenital esophageal narrowing with associated swallowing dysfunction and intermittent regurgitation. Past evaluations have documented a structural brain malformation consistent with congenital underdevelopment of the cerebral hemispheres, correlating with his cognitive profile and delayed motor milestones. Examination has also described multiple congenital anomalies, including a recognized pattern of skeletal and craniofacial differences with mild facial dysmorphism, as well as a small, congenitally malformed kidney contributing to longstanding concerns regarding renal structure, though kidney function has remained clinically monitored. Overall appearance suggests an underlying syndromic etiology with multisystem involvement. Prior genetic testing included a targeted gene panel performed on 2025-05-30, which was reported as negative, without identification of a causative variant. He presents today for further etiologic clarification and ongoing management planning.

Charles Martinez is a 16-year-old male with a longstanding history of significant developmental impairment and multiple congenital anomalies. Since early childhood, he has demonstrated severe intellectual disability, with minimal functional academic skills and dependence on caregivers for most activities of daily living. History is notable for a repaired congenital cardiac septal defect in infancy, with no recent reports of cyanosis or heart failure symptoms. He was also born with an upper esophageal structural abnormality causing early feeding difficulties, poor weight gain, and recurrent aspiration episodes, now partially mitigated by prior surgical intervention and modified diet. Physical examination over the years has described a pattern of dysmorphic features consistent with a recognizable congenital syndrome, including characteristic craniofacial proportions and mild skeletal anomalies. There is no known family history of similar neurodevelopmental or structural anomalies. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-01-21, which was reported as negative, and he is now referred for further genomic assessment to clarify the underlying etiology and assist with prognosis and family counseling.

Nancy Nguyen is a 4‑year‑old girl with a history notable for congenital brain malformation identified in infancy, with imaging consistent with lissencephaly and associated global developmental delay. Parents report persistent hypotonia and poor head control in early life, followed by delayed attainment of motor and language milestones; she currently has limited expressive language and requires assistance with most activities of daily living. Attention and concentration are impaired, with difficulty sustaining focus on age‑appropriate tasks. Feeding history includes early swallowing difficulties, with episodes of choking on liquids and concern for esophageal dysmotility; she remains on modified textures. Physical examination is remarkable for multiple dysmorphic features, including abnormal craniofacial proportions and asymmetry of the skull and facial structures, in keeping with a recognized pattern of congenital malformation syndrome. No seizures have been documented to date. There is no known parental consanguinity, and family history is noncontributory for similar neurodevelopmental or structural anomalies. Prior genetic evaluation with a single‑gene test on 2025‑02‑24 was negative, and broader genetic testing is now being pursued for etiologic clarification and counseling.

James Hill is an 9-year-old boy with a history notable for global developmental delay and severe intellectual impairment, with limited expressive language and need for assistance in most activities of daily living. Since early childhood, caregivers have observed slow acquisition of motor milestones and persistent learning difficulties requiring placement in a specialized education program. Clinically, he shows a recognizable pattern of congenital anomalies and distinctive facial features, including a prominent forehead, downslanting palpebral fissures, and a thin upper lip, along with mild joint laxity and proportionate short stature. Cardiac history includes a small defect in the wall between the lower heart chambers identified in infancy, with intermittent follow-up by pediatric cardiology. Renal evaluation has revealed structural anomalies of both kidneys with reduced corticomedullary differentiation, monitored by nephrology for evolving kidney function. A prior single-gene test performed on 2025-03-09 was negative, and no molecular diagnosis has yet been established. Parents report no known family history of similar developmental or structural concerns.

Richard Ramirez is a 5-year-old boy with a history notable for global developmental delay, early hypotonia, and recurrent focal seizures beginning in early childhood, some of which have secondarily generalized. Seizure frequency has fluctuated despite multiple antiseizure medications, and recent episodes have included prolonged focal impaired-awareness events requiring emergency evaluation. Parents report intermittent regression in speech and fine motor skills following clusters of seizures, with slow and incomplete recovery. Developmentally, he walked later than expected and continues to require support for balance and coordination; fine motor skills and expressive language remain significantly delayed compared with peers. Examination has previously documented mild facial dysmorphism and subtle limb asymmetry, along with decreased muscle tone and reduced endurance. There is concern for an underlying metabolic or mitochondrial disorder given episodic fatigue, poor exercise tolerance, and occasional unexplained elevations in serum biochemical markers. Family history is notable for a paternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy and learning difficulties. Prior genetic testing with a single-gene assay on 2025-07-24 was negative.

Christopher Wright is a 3-year-old boy with a history notable for severe global developmental delay and intellectual disability; he is nonverbal, dependent for all activities of daily living, and has not achieved independent ambulation. Since infancy, his course has been complicated by congenital brain malformation characterized by absence of the corpus callosum, with associated hypotonia and poor motor coordination. Craniofacial features include frontal bossing, midface hypoplasia, and mild micrognathia, with asymmetric skull shape consistent with plagiocephaly. He also has features suggestive of a congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple organ systems, including bilateral renal cystic changes identified on prior imaging, without current evidence of renal insufficiency. Growth parameters show proportionate short stature with relatively small head circumference. Birth history is reported as full-term without major perinatal complications. There is no known family history of similar neurodevelopmental or structural anomalies. Prior genetic evaluation with chromosomal microarray on 2025-08-21 was reported as negative, with no pathogenic copy number variants identified. He is followed by neurology, nephrology, and developmental pediatrics, and receives PT, OT, and speech services.

Donald Perez is a 11-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent seizures beginning in early childhood, described as generalized convulsive events with loss of consciousness and postictal confusion. Despite treatment, he has experienced breakthrough episodes, some occurring in clusters and occasionally requiring emergency evaluation. Parents report intermittent staring spells and nocturnal events suggestive of ongoing seizure activity. Clinical concerns also include difficulty tolerating dairy products, with abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools following ingestion of milk or ice cream; symptoms improve with lactose restriction and use of lactose-free alternatives. Growth and school performance are otherwise reported as appropriate for age. There is a family history of seizures in a maternal uncle, who developed epilepsy in adolescence and continues on antiseizure medication. The patient’s mother reports lifelong “sensitivity” to dairy with similar gastrointestinal symptoms but has never undergone formal evaluation. No known consanguinity is reported.

Helen Carter is a 11-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent episodes of altered consciousness associated with generalized seizures, some occurring without a clear precipitant. Parents describe events beginning in early childhood with brief staring spells that progressed to more prolonged convulsive episodes, occasionally clustering over several days. Several seizures have been accompanied by vomiting, tachypnea, and laboratory evidence of metabolic derangement, including low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap, raising concern for recurrent metabolic acidosis in the setting of her neurologic events. Between episodes she returns to her neurological baseline, though she reports intermittent fatigue and headaches. There is no known exposure to toxins or ingestions, and no clear dietary trigger has been identified. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that resolved in adolescence, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. No known consanguinity is reported. Helen is followed by neurology and metabolic specialists, and the current evaluation is focused on clarifying an underlying etiology that might unify her seizure disorder and recurrent acidosis.

Sarah Anderson is a 6-year-old girl with a history notable for moderate intellectual disability and global developmental delay. She walked independently at approximately 2½ years and continues to require support with self-care and academic skills; expressive language is limited to short phrases, with relatively better comprehension of simple commands. Since infancy, she has demonstrated distinctive craniofacial features, including a long face with prominent nasal bridge and mild malar flattening, along with asymmetry of the skull and facial structures consistent with congenital craniofacial disproportion. Head shape abnormalities have been present since early life, with persistent plagiocephaly despite repositioning strategies. Ophthalmologic history includes congenital ptosis with intermittent compensatory brow elevation; no prior ocular surgery is documented. She also has a history of congenital esophageal narrowing, with early feeding difficulties, episodic dysphagia, and prior evaluation for poor weight gain in toddler years, now improved with dietary modification. Prior genetic testing with a neurodevelopmental gene panel, completed on 2025-09-22, was reported as negative. She currently receives school-based speech and occupational therapies and lives with both parents.

Kimberly White is a 13-year-old girl with a history notable for recurrent episodes of metabolic decompensation characterized by nausea, malaise, and laboratory evidence of metabolic acidosis, often triggered by intercurrent illness or decreased oral intake. Parents describe intermittent fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance around these episodes, which have required several emergency evaluations for low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap, with partial improvement following intravenous fluids and electrolyte correction. Between episodes, she is generally well but has ongoing follow-up with metabolic specialists to monitor acid–base status and adjust nutritional support during periods of stress. Neurologically, clinical concerns include intermittent unsteadiness and poor coordination, particularly with tandem gait and fine motor tasks such as handwriting and buttoning clothes; teachers have reported clumsiness in gym class and difficulty with rapid alternating movements. There is no clear history of regression, seizures, or focal weakness, but mild truncal ataxia has been observed on examination. Family history is notable for a younger brother with episodic “stomach flu” and dehydration requiring IV fluids, and a maternal uncle described as “very clumsy” in childhood.

Thomas Walker is a 6-year-old boy (born 2019-11-21) seen for ongoing neurological and metabolic concerns. History is notable for recurrent episodes of altered responsiveness associated with generalized convulsive events, described by parents as sudden stiffening followed by rhythmic jerking of all extremities, with postictal sleepiness and confusion. Events have occurred without clear provocation, including during sleep and quiet wakefulness. Clinical concerns also include intermittent metabolic decompensation characterized by lethargy, tachypnea, and laboratory evidence of metabolic acidosis, occasionally requiring emergency department evaluation and intravenous fluids. Parents report decreased exercise tolerance during intercurrent illnesses, with poor oral intake and vomiting. Developmental progress has otherwise been appropriate for age. There is no history of significant head trauma or central nervous system infection. Family history is positive for a paternal uncle with childhood-onset seizures that resolved in adolescence, and a maternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. No known consanguinity is reported. Thomas lives with both parents, attends kindergarten, and is not on any chronic antiseizure or metabolic medications at this time.

Ruth Hernandez is a 5-year-old girl with a history notable for episodes of unprovoked seizures beginning in early childhood, described as generalized stiffening with loss of awareness followed by postictal fatigue. Parents also report intermittent concerns for poor energy and possible metabolic instability, including reduced exercise tolerance and prolonged recovery after minor illnesses, though growth has remained appropriate. Clinical course is further complicated by a prior superficial facial burn from accidental hot liquid exposure and a separate right ankle injury consistent with a sprain, both attributed to age-appropriate accidents without concern for non-accidental trauma. Medication history includes prior exposure to a penicillin-class antibiotic, after which she developed diffuse rash and vomiting, raising concern for a drug-related adverse reaction; this class is now avoided. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset seizure disorder requiring long-term antiseizure therapy, and a paternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. No known consanguinity is reported. Ongoing evaluation focuses on characterization of seizure type and assessment for an underlying metabolic or mitochondrial disorder.

Steven Torres is a 3‑year‑old boy with a history notable for global developmental delay, with persistent delays in both motor and language milestones. Since infancy, he has shown features suggestive of a congenital patterning syndrome, including facial asymmetry and other subtle craniofacial differences, along with generalized hypotonia and poor coordination contributing to delayed independent walking. Clinical concerns include feeding difficulties related to a congenital narrowing in the upper esophagus, with intermittent choking and poor weight gain. Orthopedic evaluation documented congenital deformity of the feet with abnormal positioning at rest and on weight bearing. Examination is further notable for asymmetry of the external ears, with one ear smaller and more posteriorly rotated, raising concern for an underlying syndromic etiology. Past history also includes a prior superficial facial laceration involving the scalp and a thermal injury to the head region without reported loss of consciousness or lasting neurologic deficit. Prior genetic evaluation with single‑gene testing on 2025‑10‑03 was negative, and no definitive molecular diagnosis has yet been established.

Kenneth Torres is a 3-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent seizures beginning in early childhood, described as generalized convulsive episodes without clear provoking factors. Parents report several emergency visits during which he was found to have significant metabolic acidosis with low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap, occasionally in the setting of intercurrent illness and poor oral intake. Clinical concerns also include an episode of right ankle pain and swelling after a twisting injury while running, with difficulty bearing weight and localized tenderness, treated as a lateral ankle sprain without fracture on imaging. More recently, he experienced an adverse reaction after receiving a penicillin-class antibiotic, with onset of neurologic symptoms and worsening metabolic derangement temporally associated with the medication exposure, prompting discontinuation and avoidance of this drug class. Family history is notable for a paternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy requiring long-term antiseizure therapy, and a maternal grandmother with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. No known consanguinity is reported.

Daniel Miller is an 8-year-old boy (DOB 2017-08-19) seen for follow-up of complex medical issues. History is notable for recurrent metabolic decompensation characterized by episodes of metabolic acidosis with low bicarbonate and compensatory tachypnea during intercurrent illnesses, requiring IV fluids and close monitoring. Neurologically, he has had intermittent generalized hypotonia since early childhood, most apparent during febrile episodes, with delayed recovery of baseline strength but otherwise stable gross motor skills between illnesses. Past history includes a prior mild closed head injury without loss of consciousness after a fall from standing height; no persistent post-concussive symptoms have been reported. He also sustained a superficial facial burn from scalding liquid in early childhood, which healed without contractures. Medication history includes a documented adverse reaction to penicillin-class antibiotics with significant systemic symptoms, and these agents are now avoided. Family history is positive for a paternal uncle with recurrent unexplained “acid buildup in the blood” requiring hospitalizations and a maternal grandfather with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.

Laura Lewis is a 14-year-old girl (DOB 2011-08-16) referred for evaluation of multiple congenital anomalies and developmental concerns. Since infancy, growth has been suboptimal with persistent short stature and delayed attainment of motor and language milestones; she continues to require academic support at school. History is notable for external ear malformation with asymmetric auricular structure and mild conductive hearing issues, as well as a congenital cardiac outflow tract defect involving the pulmonary valve that was surgically repaired in early childhood but still requires cardiology follow-up. She has a recognizable pattern of craniofacial differences, including abnormal skull and facial shape with mild midface asymmetry, prompting consideration of an underlying syndromic diagnosis. Past history also includes a prior mild closed head injury without loss of consciousness, a superficial facial laceration to the scalp region, and a superficial facial burn, all of which have healed without clear long-term sequelae. Prior genetic testing with chromosomal microarray on 2025-10-25 was reported as negative, and no molecular diagnosis has yet been established.

Steven Garcia is a 17-year-old male presenting for follow-up after recent acute medical events. History is notable for treatment with a penicillin-class antibiotic, after which he experienced no documented allergic reaction but required monitoring given the context of acute care. More recently, he sustained a right ankle injury consistent with a sprain following a sports-related twisting mechanism; he reported localized pain and difficulty bearing weight, with swelling but no obvious deformity. Conservative management with rest, ice, compression, elevation, and activity modification was initiated, and he reports gradual improvement, though he continues to experience intermittent discomfort with strenuous activity. Additionally, he has a history of a mild head injury without reported loss of consciousness, followed by transient headache and brief dizziness; there were no focal neurological deficits on examination. He was advised on return-to-play precautions and monitoring for post-concussive symptoms. Developmental and academic progress are described as age-appropriate, and there are no reported chronic medical conditions or significant psychiatric concerns at this time.

Sarah Harris is a 7-year-old girl who presents today for evaluation following multiple recent traumatic injuries. History is notable for a right ankle sprain sustained after twisting her ankle while running at school, resulting in lateral ankle pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight. A separate incident involved a laceration of the scalp after striking her head on playground equipment; bleeding was controlled with local pressure, and there was no reported loss of consciousness, vomiting, or seizure activity. More recently, she sustained a superficial burn to the face when briefly exposed to hot liquid in the kitchen, leading to erythema and tenderness over the affected area without blistering or respiratory compromise. Parents report that Sarah is otherwise healthy, with normal growth and development and no prior significant medical or surgical history. Immunizations are reported to be up to date. There is no known family history of bleeding disorders, connective tissue disease, or recurrent fractures. On review, there are no chronic medications, and she has no known drug allergies.

George Perez is a 18-year-old male presenting after a recent right ankle injury sustained while playing soccer, with twisting of the ankle followed by immediate pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight. Examination in the emergency setting reportedly showed lateral ankle tenderness and soft tissue swelling without obvious deformity; plain radiographs were obtained to assess for fracture, and he was treated with immobilization and activity restriction. Since the injury, he reports persistent discomfort with ambulation and sports, though symptoms have been gradually improving. Clinical history is also notable for an episode of adverse reaction following penicillin-class antibiotic exposure earlier this year, characterized by acute onset of diffuse pruritic rash and mild facial swelling within hours of the first dose, requiring discontinuation of the medication and treatment with antihistamines in urgent care. There is no documentation of respiratory compromise, but he has been advised to avoid this antibiotic class pending formal allergy evaluation. No additional chronic medical problems, surgeries, or hospitalizations are documented in the available record.

Brian Martin is a 7-year-old boy who presents today for follow-up after multiple recent injuries. History is notable for a superficial burn involving the head and face sustained when he accidentally spilled hot liquid on himself; the affected area was initially erythematous and painful without evidence of deep tissue involvement or inhalation injury. More recently, he experienced an inversion injury to the right ankle while playing sports, with immediate pain and difficulty bearing weight; examination at that time was consistent with a lateral ankle sprain, and imaging reportedly showed no fracture. Additionally, Brian had a prior mild head injury without documented loss of consciousness following a fall from standing height; he was briefly dazed but recovered quickly, and there have been no persistent headaches, vomiting, behavioral change, or academic decline reported since that event. There is no documented family history of similar trauma patterns or bleeding disorders. He is otherwise described as active and developmentally appropriate, with no chronic medical conditions reported.

Andrew Ramirez is a 3-year-old boy (born 13 November 2022) seen in follow-up after an acute head injury and associated burn. History is notable for a recent closed head trauma without documented loss of consciousness. Caregivers report that immediately after the incident he cried promptly and has since remained interactive at his neurological baseline, with no witnessed seizures, persistent vomiting, or focal weakness. They do note some irritability and transient sleep disruption over the days following the event. Clinical concerns also include a superficial burn injury involving the head/face region sustained at the same time, reportedly from contact with a hot surface. The burn was initially managed with local wound care; there has been no evidence of infection, and dressings are being changed as instructed. On current review, parents deny visual changes, imbalance, or behavioral regression. No prior genetic testing has been performed. There is no known family history of neurological disorders, bleeding diathesis, or recurrent injuries, and no consanguinity is reported.

Robert Sanchez is a 6-year-old boy with a history notable for recurrent generalized seizures beginning in early childhood, now characterized by episodes that are difficult to control despite standard antiepileptic therapy. Parents describe abrupt staring spells and convulsive events with postictal confusion and occasional incontinence, occurring several times per month, with no clear provoking factors. Clinical concerns also include persistently abnormal laboratory findings suggesting a possible underlying metabolic disturbance, with intermittently elevated serum markers under ongoing evaluation by his primary team. Developmental progress has been largely age appropriate per parental report. There is a positive family history of neurological disease, including a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy requiring long-term medication. The paternal side is notable for a grandfather with type 2 diabetes and a paternal aunt with autoimmune thyroid disease. No known consanguinity is reported. Robert lives with both parents and attends school with some accommodations during seizure-prone periods. He is referred today for further evaluation of his seizure disorder and possible metabolic contribution to his presentation.

Paul Brown is a 7-year-old boy referred for evaluation of global developmental delay and congenital anomalies. Since early childhood, he has demonstrated significantly limited cognitive and adaptive functioning, requiring support with daily activities and specialized educational services. History is notable for congenital hydrocephalus identified in infancy, with progressive macrocephaly and need for ongoing neurosurgical and neurologic monitoring. Parents report longstanding feeding difficulties and choking episodes, and prior records describe a congenital narrowing at the junction of the throat and esophagus. Examination has consistently documented abnormal head and facial proportions with features suggestive of an underlying craniofacial syndrome and generalized body asymmetry. There is also a history of congenital spinal curvature contributing to postural imbalance. A prior single-gene test performed on 2025-11-13 was negative for the suspected condition at that time. Family history reveals a paternal grandfather with late-onset Parkinson’s disease and a maternal aunt with autoimmune thyroid disease; no known relatives with similar neurodevelopmental or structural brain abnormalities are reported.

Matthew Flores is a 5-year-old boy with a history notable for global developmental delay in the severe range, with limited expressive language and dependence on caregivers for most activities of daily living. Since infancy, parents have observed poor developmental progress and hypotonia, with delayed motor milestones; he began sitting independently well after the expected age and remains unsteady with ambulation. Facial features are described as mildly unusual, with a broad nasal bridge, low-set ears, and subtle asymmetry, raising concern for an underlying congenital syndrome. Clinical concerns also include abnormalities of the external ears and periorbital region, with a history of congenital eyelid malposition and auricular malformation noted on prior examinations. There is no known consanguinity. Family history is notable for a paternal grandfather with late-onset Parkinson’s disease and a maternal aunt with autoimmune thyroid disease. Prior genetic evaluation included chromosomal microarray performed on 10/24/2025, which was reported as negative, and further genetic testing is now being pursued to clarify an underlying syndromic etiology.

Thomas Lopez is a 13-year-old boy with a history notable for global developmental delay, with persistent lag in both motor and language milestones and ongoing need for academic support. Since infancy, he has had multiple congenital anomalies, including a congenital malformation of the pulmonary valve associated with a heart murmur and exertional fatigue, as well as a clubfoot deformity that required casting and bracing and still affects his gait. Ophthalmologic history includes drooping of one upper eyelid, for which he has been followed by pediatric ophthalmology. Physical examination has been described as consistent with a recognizable pattern of congenital anomalies and distinctive facial features, raising concern for an underlying syndromic diagnosis. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-05-19, which was reported as negative. Family history is notable for a paternal grandfather with late-onset colon cancer and a maternal aunt with hypothyroidism; there is no known consanguinity.

Jessica Adams is a 6-year-old girl with a history of recurrent generalized seizures beginning in early childhood, described as sudden loss of awareness with tonic-clonic activity and postictal confusion, occurring despite antiseizure therapy titration. Episodes have occasionally clustered, requiring emergency care. Parents also report intermittent staring spells suggestive of absence events, though these have been less clearly characterized. Clinical concerns further include gastrointestinal discomfort, bloating, and loose stools following ingestion of dairy products, leading the family to largely restrict milk and ice cream; symptoms improve with avoidance and use of lactose-free alternatives. Growth and overall development have been appropriate for age. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset epilepsy that persisted into adulthood, and a paternal cousin with “severe milk intolerance” requiring strict dietary modification. Additional history includes a maternal grandmother with rheumatoid arthritis and a father with early-onset hypertension. Prior genetic testing performed on 2022-05-18 reportedly showed no pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants, and no clear etiology for the seizure disorder was identified.
